titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Robert J. Corry Papers, 1953-2001 UA.90.F59
titlestmt.author: Jamie Peretich.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-08 17:35:43 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Robert J. Corry was an influential pancreatic transplant surgeon who came to the University of Pittsburgh from the University of Iowa in 1994. He was a member of more than 30 professional societies and organizations, and served as president the United Network for Organ Sharing from 1989 to 1990. This collection spans the professional career of Robert Corry, focusing heavily on Corry's research and publications, although presentations and conference proceedings are also abundant.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Robert J. Corry, a Cleveland native, began his career at Yale University, where he graduated magna cum laude in 1957. He then enrolled at Johns Hopkins University, graduating in 1961. After completing an internship in pediatrics and surgery at John Hopkins in 1963, Corry completed a residency and fellowship in surgery at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital and Massachusetts General Hospital at Harvard University. His academic career began at Harvard in 1968, where he was appointed assistant professor of surgery in 1972.

In 1973, Corry went to the University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics, where he joined the faculty of the University of Iowa College of Medicine as associate professor of surgery and became director of transplantation at the University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics and the VA Medical Center, Iowa City. In 1976, he was promoted to professor of surgery and in 1982, chief of surgery. He held both of these positions until he was recruited in 1994 by UPMC to head the pancreatic transplant program. From 1999 to 2000, he was one of four vice presidents of the medical staff at UPMC Presbyterian.

Robert J. Corry performed the first combined liver and pancreas excision from a single donor and transplanted the organs into two recipients. He performed more than 350 pancreas transplantations, 180 kidney transplants and 50 liver transplants. He was a member of more than 30 professional societies and organizations, including the presidency of American Society of Transplant Surgeons (1986-87). He also served as president the United Network for Organ Sharing (1989-1990). From 1995 to his death on 11 February 2002, Corry also served on the board of directors for the Pittsburgh chapter of the Transplant Recipients International Organization.

Corry's research and clinical interests included exploring methods to control organ rejection and induce tolerance, identifying ways to expand the donor pool, such as using organs from older donors, and working to develop policies for broader sharing of pancreases within the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The collection spans the professional career of Robert J. Corry, from the beginning of his collegiate education at Yale in 1953 until his death in early 2002. It focuses heavily on Corry's research and publications, although presentations and conference proceedings are also abundant. The collection includes correspondence, research notes and materials, publications, presentation materials, and photographs and slides.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Additional notes are found at the series level. The collection has been arranged into nine series:
Series I. Publications, 1960-2001
Series II. Books and Chapters
Series III. Talks
Series IV. Research
Series V. Grants
Series VI. Professional Activities
Series VII. Administrative
Series VIII. Education
Series IX. Media

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Some materials in Series VII are restricted to protect privacy. For questions about conditions of access, contact the University Archivist.

acqinfo.head: Acqisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Robert J. Corry estate in 2002.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Robert J. Corry Papers, 1953-2001, UA.90.F59, University Archives, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.p: Robert J. Corry Papers, 1953-2001, UA.90.F59, University Archives, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Jamie Peretich in May 2005.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Permission for publication is given on behalf of the University of Pittsburgh as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission of the copyright holder, which must also be obtained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains a chronological arrangement of articles published in various periodicals, authored or co-authored by Robert Corry. Individual articles are contained in each folder, and in some cases, additional materials such as correspondence, drafts, and research articles are also included in the folder. The first several words of each article title are indicated in the following folder list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains both published and unpublished articles and chapters, authored or co-authored by Corry, that were to be included in monographs. The series is arranged in rough chronological order. Information about each chapter in this series may include drafts, reprints, notes, and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents which relate to various talks given by Corry to a variety of professional, student, international, and community groups. Items are arranged chronologically. The materials representing each talk may include speech notes, drafts, eventual publications of the remarks, and visual aid materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials relevant to research in which Robert Corry participated. Information includes meeting notes, funding information, relevant articles, results, procedures, and other notes. Materials are roughly arranged by research subject.

did.unittitle: Meeting c. Nippon Kayaku and Bristol-Myers re 15-deoxy, Chicago
Hypertology of Rat Kidneys - data and reports
Animal application for research, university of Pittsburgh

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials which relate to grants for which Corry applied or received funding. Materials include draft proposals, submitted proposals, result reports, and meeting notes. Materials are arranged in a roughly chronological order: however, not all materials are dated.

did.unittitle: Grant award: mechanism of transfusion in improving allograft survival, National institute of arthritis
Characterization of transfusion-induced suppressor cells, DHHS
Grant application: immuno suppression by en bloc
Grant application - combined bone marrow and organ transplantation in humans
Grant application JDFI - John Fung's contribution

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains a wide variety of materials, all of which relate to the professional development and visibility of Robert Corry. This includes article review commentaries, articles read by Corry to keep current in the field, membership in professional associations, newspaper articles about Corry and transplantation programs in Iowa and Pittsburgh, and related meetings and correspondence.

did.unittitle: International pancreas transplant registry, advisory committee invite
UNOS: New transplant laws, Hunsicker correspondence
First international symposium on hereditary pancreatitus
Spectation, University of Iowa newspaper special feature on surgery
Newspaper articles and editorials: UIHC v. Des Moines hospitals, newspaper clippings
Cedar Rapids Gazette series on transplantation, clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information used by Corry during the course of his professional activities. This material includes correspondence, procedures and protocols, departmental organization information and reviews, patient information, surgery reports, and personal information such as Corry's CV and photographs related to professional organizations.
To protect the privacy of individuals, some files in Boxes 5, 6 and 7 are restricted. For questions about conditions of access, contact the University Archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These records come from Corry's undergraduate career at Yale University between 1953 and 1957. They include notes, syllabi, tests, and assignments from classes he attended.

did.unittitle: History of East Asian Civilizations course

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains various slides, transparencies, and photographs which were likely used by Corry for presentations, talks, and educational activities.
